name: 北方文藝復興
description: 探討北方文藝復興藝術的演變與社會、文化、政治的關係，重要藝術家作品的特色，贊助者與重要工作坊的傳承，南、北方文藝復興藝術的交流，宗教改革對北方文藝復興藝術的影響等等議題，以增進對北方文藝復興藝術概觀性的認識，以及對相關議題的分析能力。
goals: To create a wide-ranging knowledge and understanding of key developments in the visual arts and related cultures north of the Alps in the Renaissance.
To train students’ ability to analyse form and iconography using correct terminology.
To improve students’ ability in making aesthetic judgments.
To instruct students how to find and interpret sources of art historical theory.
To promote students’ competencies in collecting and interpreting related literature while maintaining a critical attitude toward scholarly opinions.
To give technical instructions for writing an academic text and composing a paper.
syllabus:
1.    Introduction

a)    overview of the subject content, explanation of class procedures and scholarly methodology, and details of the assessment, including discussion and distribution of topics for student presentations and papers

b)   centres of political and economic power in northern Europe from the late fourteenth century: a brief account of the Valois kings of France, the duchies of Burgundy, Berry, and Anjou, the Holy Roman Empire, and England

2.    Sculpture for the Burgundian Court in Dijon

a)    Claus Sluter, _Well of Moses,_ 1396–1405, ex-Chartreuse de la Sainte-Trinité de Champmol, Dijon

b)   Claus Sluter, _Virgin and Child, Saints John and Catherine, and Philip the Bold and Margaret of Flanders_, 1389–1406, ex-Chartreuse de la Sainte-Trinité de Champmol, Dijon

c)    Claus Sluter, Jean de Marville, Claus de Werve, and Jean Malouel, Tomb of Philip the Bold, 1404–1410, Musée des Beaux-Arts de Dijon

3.    Luxury Manuscripts for Private Devotions of the Nobility

a)    French and Netherlandish, Turin-Milan Hours, illuminated early-to-mid 1400s, Bibliothèque nationale de France, Paris; Museo civico d’arte, Turin; and J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles

b)   Master of Catherine of Cleves, Hours of Catherine of Cleves, c. 1440, Morgan Library and Museum, New York,

c)    Jean Le Tavernier and others, Hours of Philip the Good, 1454–1455, Koninklijke Bibliotheek, The Hague

4.    Robert Campin, His Tournai Workshop, and Apprentices

a)    Campin and Workshop, _Virgin and Child_; _Saint Veronica_; and _Trinity_, all c. 1430, Städel Museum, Frankfurt am Main

b)   Jacques Daret, _Visitation_, 1433–1435, Staatlichen Museen zu Berlin; _Adoration of the Magi_, 1433–1435, Staatlichen Museen zu Berlin; _Nativity_, 1433–1435, Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza, Madrid; and _Presentation in the Temple_, 1433–1435, Musée des Beaux-Arts de la Ville de [Paris](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris)

c)    Rogier van der Weyden, _Descent from the Cross_, c. 1435, Museo del Prado, Madrid

5.    _Devotio moderna_ and the Domestic Context of Religious Images

a)    Robert Campin, _Trinity_; _Virgin and Child by a Fireplace_, early 1430s, State Hermitage Museum. Saint Petersburg

b)   Jan van Eyck (and workshop?), _Virgin and Child with a Book_, 1433, National Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne

c)    Petrus Christus, _Virgin and Child in an Interior_, c. 1450, Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, Kansas City

6.    Hubert and Jan van Eyck in Ghent

a)    Hubert and Jan van Eyck, The Ghent Altarpiece, 1432, La Cathédrale Saint-Bavon, Ghent

7.    Jan van Eyck and His Bruges Workshop

a)    Jan van Eyck, _Portrait of a Man (Self-Portrait?)_, 1433, National Gallery, London

b)   Jan van Eyck, _Portrait of Giovanni (?) Arnolfini and his Wife_, 1434, National Gallery, London

c)    Jan van Eyck, _Stigmatization of Saint Francis_, 1430s, Galleria Sabauda, Turin, and _Stigmatization of Saint Francis_, 1430s, Philadelphia Museum of Art

8.    The Patronage of Nicolas Rolin

a)    Jan van Eyck, _Virgin and Child with Nicolas Rolin_, c. 1435, Musée du Louvre, Paris

b)   Rogier van der Weyden, _Last Judgment_ Altarpiece, 1443, Musée de l’Hôtel Dieu, Beaune

9.    Rogier van der Weyden, Official Painter of Brussels

a)    Rogier van der Weyden, _Portrait of a Woman_, c. 1445, Staatliche Museen, Berlin

b)   Rogier van der Weyden, _Portrait of Charles the Bold_, c. 1460, Staatliche Museen, Berlin

c)    Rogier van der Weyden, _Portrait of Francesco d’Este_, c. 1460, Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.

10.      The Goldsmith’s Art

a)    Jan van Eyck, _Portrait of Jan de Leeuw_, 1436, Kunsthistorisches Museum, Vienna

b)   Gerard Loyet de Lille, _Saint George with Charles the Bold_, 1467–1471, La Cathédrale Saint-Paul de Liège

c)    Netherlandish, _Collar of the Order of the Golden Fleece_, mid-1400s, Kunsthistorisches Museum, Vienna

11.      Tournaments, Feasts, and Ceremonial Entrances

a)    Master of the Princely Portraits, _Shield of Parade_, c. 1470, British Museum, London

b)   Rogier van der Weyden, _Portrait of Anthony of Burgundy_, c. 1460, Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts, Brussels

c)    Master of the Legend of Saint Catherine, Master of the Princely Portraits, and Aert van den Bossche, _Triptych with the Miracles of Christ_, c. 1488, National Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne

12.      Hieronymus Bosch’s Religious Fantasies

a)    Hieronymus Bosch, _Garden of Earthly Delights_ triptych c. 1490–1510, Museo del Prado, Madrid

b)   Hieronymus Bosch, _Temptation of Saint Anthony_ triptych c. 1501, Museu Nacional de Arte Antiga, Lisbon

c)    Hieronymus Bosch, _Ship of Fools_, c. 1500–1510, Musée du Louvre Paris

13.      Images Made By and For Women

a)    The visual culture of the Benediktinerinnen-Abtei St. Walburg, Eichsättt, in Germany, in the late-fifteenth century

14.      Art for the Court of François I

a)    Jean Clouet, _Allegorical Portrait of François I As John the Baptist_, 1518, Musée du Louvre, Paris

b)   Jean Clouet, _Portrait of François I, King of France_, c. 1525, Musée du Louvre, Paris

15.      German Print Culture

a)    Martin Schongauer, _The Censor_, 1491, Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

b)   Albrecht Dürer, _Knight, Death and the Devil_, 1513, British Museum, London 

 Adam and Eve

c)    Albrecht Dürer, _Melancholia I_, 1514, British Museum, London

16.      Lucas Cranach and the Protestant Reformation

a)    Lucas Cranach the Elder, _Portrait of Martin Luther_, 1532, Statens Museum for Kunst, Copenhagen

b)   Lucas Cranach the Younger, _Portrait of Philipp Melanchthon_, 1544, Private Collection

17.      Hans Holbein in England

a)    Hans Holbein the Younger, _Portrait of a Lady with a Squirrel and a Starling_, c. 1527, National Gallery, London

b)   Hans Holbein the Younger, _Portrait of Jean de Dinteville and Georges de Selve_ (\`_The Ambassadors_'), 1533, National Gallery, London

c)    Hans Holbein the Younger, _Portrait of Henry VIII_, 1536, Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza, Madrid

18.     Exchanges Between the Northern Renaissance, the Mediterranean Renaissance, and the Levant

methodologies.note: a one hour presentation each week, for 18 weeks, by the Professor
a one-to-two hour discussion each week, over 18 weeks, led by the Professor, based on set readings and the case studies listed in the weekly schedule of this syllabus
Non-assessed homework tasks may be given, requiring students to apply visual analysis and research methodologies to set artworks.
Students will consult ultra-high resolution images of artworks, available from Google Cultural Institute.
Students will select a case study from the list in the syllabus schedule, or another example chosen in consultation with the professor, as the basis for their assessed oral presentation.

grading.note: a written paper, in essay form, between 10 and 14 pages long
an oral presentation, with visual aids, of around 45 minutes
